factoid: The song said, "She let the hawk fly upward from her wide right sleeve."
The song aroused an involuntary sensation of courage and cheerfulness.
The conversation would probably have been different if not for the effect of that song.
Dólokhov asked if it was true that Austrians had been beaten.
The reply was, "The devil only knows! They say so."
Dólokhov answered, "I'm glad," briefly and clearly, as the song demanded.
Zherkóv said, "Come round some evening and we'll have a game of faro!"
Zherkóv asked, "Why, have you too much money?"
Zherkóv replied, "Do come."
Dólokhov said, "I can't. I've sworn not to. I won't drink and won't play till I get reinstated."
Dólokhov said, "Well, that's only till the first engagement."
Dólokhov said, "We shall see."
Dólokhov said, "Come if you need anything. One can at least be of use on the staff."
Dólokhov smiled and said, "Don't trouble. If I want anything, I won't beg—I’ll take it!"
Dólokhov said, "Well, never mind; I only…"
Dólokhov said, "And I only…"
Dólokhov said, "Good-by."
Dólokhov said, "Good health…"
The quoted speech was, "It’s a long, long way. To my native land…"
Zherkóv touched his horse with spurs.
The horse pranced excitedly from foot to foot uncertain with which to start.
The horse settled down.
The horse galloped past the company.
The horse overtook the carriage.
The horse kept time to the song.
On returning from the review, Kutúzov took the Austrian general into his private room.
Kutúzov called his adjutant and asked for papers relating to the condition of the troops on their arrival.
Kutúzov asked for letters that had come from Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of the advanced army.
Prince Andrew Bolkónski entered the room with the required papers.
Kutúzov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriegsrath were sitting at the table on which a plan was spread out.
Kutúzov said, "Ah!..." while glancing at Bolkónski, as if asking the adjutant to wait.
Kutúzov continued the conversation in French.
Kutúzov said, "All I can say, General."
It was evident that Kutúzov listened with pleasure to his own voice.
Kutúzov said, "If the matter depended on my personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the Emperor Francis would have been fulfilled long ago."
Kutúzov said, "I should long ago have joined the Archduke."
Kutúzov said, "I would have pleasure to hand over the supreme command of the army into the hands of a better informed and more skillful general."
Kutúzov said, "Austria has many better informed and more skillful generals."
Kutúzov said, "I would lay down all this heavy responsibility."
Kutúzov said, "But circumstances are sometimes too strong for us, General."
Kutúzov smiled as if saying, "You are quite at liberty not to believe me and I don't even care whether you do or not, but you have no grounds for telling me so."
Kutúzov smiled as if saying, "And that is the whole point."
The Austrian general looked dissatisfied.
The Austrian general had no option but to reply in the same tone.
The Austrian general said, "On the contrary."
The Austrian general said, "Your excellency’s participation in the common action is highly valued by His Majesty."
The Austrian general said, "We think the present delay is depriving the splendid Russian troops and their commander of the laurels they have been accustomed to win in their battles."
The Austrian general concluded his sentence as prearranged.
Kutúzov bowed with the same smile.
Kutúzov said, "But that is my conviction."

Kutúzov said, "Judging by the last letter with which His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imagine that the Austrian troops, under the direction of General Mack, have by now already gained a decisive victory."
Kutúzov said, "The Austrian troops no longer need our aid."
The general frowned.
There was no definite news of an Austrian defeat.
There were many circumstances confirming unfavorable rumors that were afloat.
Kutúzov’s suggestion of an Austrian victory sounded like irony.
Kutúzov went on blandly smiling with the same expression.
The last letter Kutúzov received from Mack’s army informed him of a victory.
The last letter stated that the position of the army was very favorable.
